awd_titl_txt: New Frontiers in Stellar Astrophysics: Massive Stars as Cosmological Tools
awd_abstract_narration:
Stars more than 10 times as massive as the Sun are important building blocks in our Universe.  Their violent deaths in supernova explosions, in which stars are unable to hold themselves up against gravity, release new material into galaxies to form new stars.  These massive stars are bright, and thus they hold promise as distance estimators to distant galaxies.  If we know how bright a star should look, we can compare its apparent brightness to find its distance.  Unfortunately, these stars are rare and thus poorly understood at the moment.  The investigator plans to collect basic data about massive, luminous stars in other galaxies.  The observations will help us better understand the lives of these stars.  Both graduate and undergraduate students will take part in the research.  She will also work with the Zooniverse Project to convert the light variations of astronomical objects---usually conveyed visually---to sound.  This effort will be of interest to citizen scientists, particularly those who are visually impaired.

The investigator describes a multi-wavelength observing plan that covers the post-main sequence phases of stellar evolution before the stars explode as supernovae.  The ongoing HST COS far-UV SNAP program provides high S/N spectra, with better resolution, than were previously possible.  The project will sample objects of different metallicity, including extremely-metal-poor galaxies, that will serve as analogs for star formation regions in the early Universe.  The investigator will also create a comprehensive library of ultraviolet spectra using observations of 87 nearby star-forming galaxies, using these data to test the next generation of stellar population synthesis and photoionization codes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This research focused on the physical properties and evolution of massive stars (8 times as massive as our sun or more) that have completed their hydrogen-fusion phase and are approaching the ends of their lives.


The first major scientific component of this project used survey data on evolved massive stars in other galaxies to develop stellar evolution models, study these stars' evolutionary phases, and explore the recent discovery of Thorne-Zytkow objects (strange stars with the outward appearance of cold massive stars but interiors supported by quantum physics rather than standard nuclear fusion).  University of Washington graduate student and postdoctoral researcher Trevor Dorn-Wallenstein conducted this research, which ultimately comprised a large portion of his PhD thesis research. He published papers presenting how binary evolution (when stars evolve in close proximity to a gravitationally-bound companion) and rotation can impact the properties of massive stars and the appearance of a galaxy's massive star population as a whole. He also published work on using machine learning to classify evolved massive stars using only detailed studies of their brightness variations. In a series of papers he presented his discovery of a new class of massive stars known as "FYPS" (fast yellow pulsating supergiants) and, through detailed analyses of these stars' pulsations and physical properties, identified them as a compelling intermediary stage of stellar evolution that can help to explain the populations of massive stars astronomers observe dying as core-collapse supernovae. Finally, in a paper led by Ms. Lindsay DeMarchi and in collaboration with Dr. Jax Sanders, we presented a study of Thorne-Zytkow objects as potential "multi-messenger sources", producing both electromagnetic and gravitational wave signatures. We simulated the gravitational wave signatures of these objects and considered this as a potential means of identifying and studying future candidates and better understanding these strange products of massive binary evolution as a class.


The second major scientific component of this project is to study the environments of star-forming galaxies, including their spatially-resolved properties as the hosts of long-duration gamma-ray bursts (the energetic core-collapse deaths of extreme massive stars). University of Washington undergraduate student Mallory Thorp published a paper mapping the environment of the complex galaxy that hosted a gamma-ray burst in 2002, GRB 020903. This strange galaxy consisted of four interacting components; Ms. Thorp's work pinpointed the location of the gamma-ray burst, measured properties including chemical composition and the region's history of forming massive stars, and compared this to other portions of the galaxy, determining that the gamma-ray burst occurred in a fairly typical region of the galaxy.


Finally, the major goal of this project's Broader Impacts component was to develop TransientZoo, a citizen science program that would allow participants (including the visually-impaired) to classify supernovae and other transient events by "listening" to them, translating observed changes in the objects' brightness into audible changes in pitch. University of Washington undergraduate student Locke Patton wrote an open-source and broadly-applicable data sonification curve that could convert time-dependent brightness data into sound files; this work received a Chambliss Astronomy Achievement Student Award from the American Astronomical Society for its presentation at the January 2019 meeting.


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Emily Levesque
